Thousands of hours of developer's time and will-to-work will be saved by focusing on a specific browser platform. 

Chrome is the most stable across different operating systems and is open-source and supported by the billionaire club. Firefox builds are sometimes unstable and I believe developers have been paid from time-to-time by people at MS and GOOG to screw it up.

==============================
maybe the easiest way to think about this is:
to rebuild zeronet with the following properties:
1) only 1 website available on the app... a website that I will build (already built reprogrammed in python and javascript)
2) users interact with my site/app by adding to the blockchain using bitcoin addresses
3) users interact with my site/app by editing a short list of key-value pairs associated with their bitcoin address
4) all records of user activity is saved in a sqlite db that is updated accross the network and can only be edited at the points of "ownership" by the owners of the private keys associated with the bitcoin addresses related to their personal content (key-value pairs)

--- can you help me achieve this? ---

I also want all users of my app to be updated whenever legitimate updates are made, just like websites on zeronet are updated when the owner changes their personal websites, but the core program and the core sqlite db must be immutable, only editable by me(the owner of the primary private key and address) and the blockchain db can only be appended and never edited

It makes no sense to ask site visitors to host every site they visit. People are greedy. They only want to host their own sites. And who, but you the developers, will dedicate your computer hardware to hosting other people's sites? Makes no sense. We need a new algorithm for this project! Talk to me. I have a better approach.

I think that ZeroNet has its place, but the argument is about scaling. Everyone cannot host every site they visit. Some people will dedicate hardware, but most turn their computers off, and usrbtheir PC for other things... So bloat will inevitably turn off casual users. I think the point is for distributed hosting. ... And I agree with it, ZeroNet. But... But... The existing code is imensely close to a slightly different algorithm that I can use for an imensely more valuable project that is integrated superficially with the existing server-based internet infrastructure. So let's start a private discussion. Email me at everforward@live.com. If I want to save a few years of development, then I have to use zeronet code and partner with you core developers, to rebranding and trim the code. The new application client will be opensourse, as the client will be employed by every node in the network, and ownership, or more specifically : the saleable - leasable assets of the application will be held by  nodes that dedicate resources to maintaining the application's data for public reference. ... And we have a huge international market of new and existing interested parties with the resources and strong desire to participate in my network algorithm. They already spend hundreds to tens of thousands of dollars every year for the benefits my proposal will offer, and they are heavily frustrated by the corporate domination and manipulation of the service my proposed application will freely provide. So, for you as a developer of a free distributed hosting application, interest in this socialist approach to the existing internet structure should be a welcome challenge.

topic.title: frozen navigation when trying to return to main menu
topic.body:
### Step 1: Please describe your environment

  * ZeroNet version: __current download___
  * Operating system: ___windows 10, 64 bit__
  * Web browser: __Edge___
  * Tor status: not available/always/disabled -- always
  * Opened port: yes/no -- no 
  * Special configuration: _nothing special___

### Step 2: Describe the problem:
browser froze in process when trying to navigate away from GIF page
#### Steps to reproduce:
go to gif page, click around, and try to get back to the main menu... nothing happens


#### Observed Results:
no page change, no navigation
  * What happened? This could be a screenshot, a description, log output (you can send log/debug.log file to hello@zeronet.io if necessary), etc.

#### Expected Results:

  * What did you expect to happen?
return to the previous page, the main menu, or some other navigation menu via the user options button

topic.title: TOR:ALWAYS -- Using Tor for anonymity is a self-contradicting concept
topic.body: Be aware that the Tor network cannot be used for anonymity. The Tor network itself traces the origin and destination of all requests and statistics are available.

topic.title: Does not work on MS Edge. Custom ZeroNet Chromium build recommended.
topic.body: Microsoft is fighting this. The JS functionality does not work on MS Edge. I request complete departure from MS Edge compatibility, that will never be achievable.... Also custom browser from Chromium as an App to fully support ZeroNet functionality.

topic.title: User HD memory allocation should be an option at install time
topic.body: [1GB - 20GB] memory allocation slider, or as 10% available HD space

topic.title: DHT peer to peer without 3rd party references is #1 priority
Users need the option to use their own bitcoin protocol addresses to create a new site.
Minimize the complication creating a new website with simple form fields on creation. Add PHP 7
topic.body: Embed Xampp as an option, with full MYSQL and PHPADMIN and PHP 7. Wow... 1/2 a billion Indians will grab it and join the swarm.

topic.title: It looks like any application can be put in a zite folder, what are the limitations in the code? What security is built into stopping free-standing applications from being placed in a zite root directory?
topic.body: Please save me the hours of testing what you built.

topic.title: Requested link to step-by-step build instructions, with proven Python version number
topic.body: Please link us in the Readme documentation to step by step build instructions with the proven version of Python. Please specify specs for Windows, Linux and MacOs builds, and reference cached dependencies - i.e. this repo folder containing all the proven dependencies with in their proven version.

topic.title: We need a Linux server module that acts as a site specific mirror... with a dedicated IP address
topic.body: So: a zeronet site owner can also make their site available on www with a traditional URL. ... as a mirror of their zeronet based zite

topic.title: If I create 20 websites, for example, and each has its own private key, can I backup my "wallet?"
topic.body: If a user creates multiple websites and needs to save their private keys in case of a computer failure, or if they change their computer, or if they change their OS... etc. And the user wants to restore their sites and control of their sites after a system failure (or system change) is ti possible to restore their sites from the peer network, with a private backup of public-private key pairs?

topic.title: Request for complete code walk-through video for ZeroNet
topic.body: Is it possible to create a complete code walk-through video for Zero-Net, explaining everything from the entry file through all of the functions and classes?

topic.title: The problem with your file structure:
topic.body:
This is a huge issue with your file structure, and almost everyone who uses github as their code source: Your dependencies are not in your repository.

Here is the first roadblock reading your code::
I download zeronet.master unzip it, and open in Atom editor. 
--I enter the program in zeronet.py, and ignore the "import"s knowing they are simply required functions in known thirdparty code blocks...
--I find the update section in zeronet.py and comment it out... I don't want my app updating from your github repository.
--I move to the  main.py file that is initiated in zeronet.py and discover this third party file called gevent that us used to import "monkey" --- i look around in the code base and... no gevent and no monkey.

topic.title: Previous Version Reference Request
topic.body: What previous version of ZeroNet would be best for the deployment of a single website, that does not download other websites and does not include additional zero-zites, and is fully discover-able across the zeronet network? The easiest version that is fully functional with the network and has the fewest accessories.... the easiest to dissect?

topic.title: Python 3 - and the need for a compiled app
topic.body: I don't know if anyone noticed, but Python is now in version 3. This means that Visual Studio defaults to Python 3. This means that downloading Python defaults to version 3. and... more importantly... this means that ZeroNet code doesn't work in the latest version of Python.

I want to mirror a Zite on my URL, and use my ZeroNet Zite as a host of the site itself.
How can I do this? Step by step please.
